@kaijianding @KurtYoung ping

One reason this was not resolved in the initial release was I couldn't find the right "responsibility chain" to tie the closeable resource into. Essentially things that require closeable resources tend to have their own QueryRunner that closes the resources appropriately, and I didn't want to add yet another one without some significant thought regarding the best way to actually handle query resources.
I'm really in favor of this as the size is basically non-sensical
ðŸ‘ Given that is has minimal impact and has been tested

@cheddar Thanks for your reply. First ,I want to explain about byte code order. From what I learned from the current Druid codes, most of the byte code order is big endian ,except the longlong encoding type which uses the native endianness . While implementing this PR ,I also observe this rule, so ,for the mmap default implementation, there is no performance slowing down as you predicated .
For the `Memory` proposal ,could you give a link ? what about the plan ? I hope that the new proposal should also contain an high abstract interface. Something like `mmap` ã€`Unsafe` should be a specific technology implementation, which should be a choice for users to choose or implement by themselves.

@cheddar, re:

> That got me wondering if it should be introduced as an extension module?

The idea behind making it a core module is that I thought that at some point we would want to add an extension point for SQL UDFs to datasketches, approximate histograms, etc. To make that work, either the UDFs would need to be in the various extensions and they would need to require druid-sql, or the UDFs would need to be in druid-sql and it would need to require the various extensions.

The former made more sense to me, and given that implies druid-sql will one day be a dependency of a variety of extensions, it seemed like it belongs in core. Otherwise we get into extensions requiring other extensions that seem only lightly related, and that would be confusing to users.

If you have a better idea about how to handle extensions / UDFs with SQL then I am all ears.

@jon-wei thanks. fixed.

I support @cheddar, big endianness is bad, let's use native endianness.

If we decide to use `Memory` or similar `ByteBuffer` replacement (I like this idea as well), I think it should come as a separate PR and only after that this PR (modified to use Memory) should be applied.

I think the key point here is to have a good design interface , not byte code endianness implementation detail . As @cheddar  has mentioned, big endianness is a history accident. btw, the origin history reason of big endianness is some usage like `com.google.common.primitives.Ints.toByteArray` . Also `DataInput.readLong()  ,readInt() ....` can be override or refactored to have ByteOrder param.

From my opinion , `Memory` does not seem different from `IndexInput` or `IndexOutput`. And `Unsafe` is just a different implementation detail  relative to `ByteBuffer or mmap`. By the way `Memory` does not have `position, limit, mark, flip ,rewind` concepts, it would be a huge and hard work to refactor Druid codes ,as the concepts above was massively used.

I read through the druid-user poll and the two common themes for the "keep java 7 support" vote seem to be:

- Concerns about Scala compatibility (we already captured that in this ticket)
- Concerns about Hadoop, since a few people are stuck on Java 7 based Hadoop clusters that are seemingly out of their control to upgrade. I can see this being the case for centrally managed Hadoop clusters, especially if the team behind it doesn't upgrade very often.

I'm not sure if this is feasible, but we _might_ be able to keep the Hadoop indexer working on Java 7 runtimes even as the services move to requiring Java 8. The Hadoop indexer shouldn't need Jetty and if we're careful about what other Java 8 dependencies we add then we could possibly make that work.
@gianm / @dclim do you guys have a test environment setup that could capture a java7 hadoop environment?

From Cloudera's documentation (https://www.cloudera.com/documentation/enterprise/5-3-x/topics/cdh_cm_upgrading_to_jdk8.html): "Cloudera does not support a rolling upgrade to JDK 1.8. You must shut down the entire cluster."  Pretty unfortunate.
@drcrallen our "hadoop gauntlet" tests for Apache Hadoop distros run in jdk-7u71. I'm not sure about our tests for other distros, but if the Apache ones work then that's a good sign.
Going to close this, pending resolution of the druid-development thread, since that appears to be going in a different direction. May reopen it later, scoped down a bit.

@leventov @b-slim thanks for reviewing, have addressed comments.
@gianm  not sure why we need some heuristics, i think if the query contains a filter we should apply the filters first.

We always use the filter bitmap, the only question is do we intersect it with the bitmaps in the indexes of the search dimension (index-based algorithm), or do we use it to scan through the rows of the search dimensionÂ (cursor-based algorithm). Which one is faster would depend on the number of rows that match the filter and on the cardinality of the search dimensions.

@himanshug I have difficulty in making new InputFormat as you suggest.
For the case that the output of record reader is Map of column to value,
it is easily implemented by just adding several partitioned path related entries to the result of the record reader of delegating InputFormat.

However, if the output is just line of string which will be parsed later, 
it is very difficult to add additional information to that output. 
For example, if delimiter-separated text file is source, 
new InputFormat should append new columns from partitioned path with the same delimiter used in the file. 
However, delimiter information is not available to the InputFormat and will be given to the parser on later processing of the data.

And, some InputFormat uses custom output record format.
For example, OrcInputFormat use OrcStruct.
I think that means new InputFormat should handle each delegating InputFormat differently.

in peon's log, I found my task used

2.7.1 org.apache.hadoop.fs.FileSystem class:
```
@Deprecated
  protected void rename(final Path src, final Path dst,
      final Rename... options) throws IOException {
```

but druid 0.9.2 it built with version hadoop 2.3.0, which has
```
@Deprecated
  protected void rename(Path src, Path dst, Options.Rename... options)
    throws IOException
  {
```

may be the "final" modifier caused the issue.

Do you have any idea why the peon would be using hadoop-hdfs 2.7.1? (Did you configure it specially or did you replace any jars?)

Druid's hdfs storage extension is built against hadoop 2.3.0 and I wouldn't necessarily expect it to work with other versions, since it uses some protected methods.

Btw, the idea is that even if your Hadoop _cluster_ is a different version, it should be fine to use hadoop-hdfs client version 2.3.0, since the wire format hasn't changed and we're just talking to HDFS over the network.

When I start middleManager, I added `hadoop classpath` into ```-classpath``` jvm arg,  This way seems to work in previous version of druid.

If not in this way, how should we specify hadoop classpath for middleManager?

Since we run on hadoop 2.7.1/2.7.2, and sometimes we may use some job properties which only work in newer hadoop.  So I choosed to use 2.7.1 hadoop in classpath.

I worked around this problem by invoking `rename` by reflection. #3787

Its a temporary way, and I am not sure, if this way suitable to be merged into druid/master.

The issue is the `:` character in your segment path (in `2016-07-20T00:00:00.000Z_2016-07-21T00:00:00.000Z`).
I'm not sure what you used to generate the segments. Normally [druid doesn't use `:` for segments stored in HDFS](https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/da007ca3c2a7acec4b86186de95bc370d6867f6a/indexing-hadoop/src/main/java/io/druid/indexer/JobHelper.java#L585).

There's a method to hadoopify a string somewhere in the code. Suggest just using that (I'm on mobile so can't find it at the moment)

I don't see any code to encode characters to work with hdfs.

We wrapped realtime plumber in a mapreduce mapper, they are running on yarn. kafka index service is running on overlord/middle manager, it is more difficult to manage resource usage.
We also supports exactly once by write offsets on zookeeper after handoff succeed, but we still have to config window period properly.

still have some work to respect timeout and cancel behavior like other queries, so it is still WIP
